floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
Flooding is possible as the river, and its streams are rising, due to prolonged, heavy rain. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch but a particular focus is in the smaller tributaries in the Moyles Court area.
Further rainfall is forecast today which may raise levels further.
We are closely monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Consider activating any property flood protection products.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 07/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60 mAOD at 05:30 on 06/09/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 25 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 06/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible Thursday evening 5th September and Friday 6th September.
Over the last several hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Clyst and Culm and their tributaries area. This has meant that rivers are rising in response.
There may be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the rivers.
We expect the rivers to remain high throughout Friday 6th September, though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels, and this message will be updated on Friday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes

items.description: Scrase Bridge and West Common Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Scrase Bridge Stream, West Common Stream

items.message: The Scrasebridge and West Common Streams have returned nearer to normal, following intense rainfall on Thursday. Further showers are expected from 06:00 06/09/2024, which could cause river levels to rise again. Therefore this flood alert will remain in force. There remains uncertainty in the locations, and expected amounts of rainfall. If totals are near the maximums predicted, then flood impacts could be possible. Any river rise and flooding will likely occur quickly following intense downpours. Flooding could affect a small number of commercial properties on Bridge Road and residential properties on West Common Road. Odd numbered properties from 29 to 47 on Meadow Drive could be affected by flooding. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river on Bridge Road or Hickmans Lane, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We routinely clear debris from grilles through Lindfield, including the Builders Centre and Witch Inn, to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 06/09/2024.
